reviews.review_text: Oh man, Payday: The Heist... This game carries so many memories for me. I know it's old, and the community isn't really all that active anymore, but this game still kicks ♥♥♥. Now, this isn't PAYDAY 2. You won't spend very much time devising plans or sneaking around (more on that later), but instead, you have a clear objective, and then you let all hell loose with some kickass weapons. So, is this game for you? But isn't PAYDAY 2 so much better? Well, let me break this down.  In general, PAYDAY 2 has a more 'realistic' feel, with your characters movement and weapons being a little less arcadey, and more down to earth. Payday: The Heist is exactly the opposite, and it's still great. Characters are fast, weapons have dead point accuracy (most of the time, not always) and in general it's trying to make you feel as little vulnerability as possible. And although you could argue about which is better, there's no denying it feels pretty badass.  Another key difference is that one of PAYDAY 2's main selling points is that things within the heists switch around, making things more unique. The original lacks this in every single heist but one (which is my favourite, personally) and it does definitely wear on you after a while, however if your anything like me you'll play them again just because it's fun.  I'm almost done with comparisons! Another big one is that outside of the beggining of two heists, there's no stealth, only guns blazing. So if your really into stealth, you'll probably prefer PAYDAY 2.  And finally, the upgrade system. In PAYDAY 2, upgrading is quite complex. You have skill trees, even skill decks for bonuses, individual weapon upgrades, etc, making a very deep (albeit sometimes confusing) way to make your character powerful. The original streamlines this: All you have to do is pick which tree to advance in, and as you level up you get things from that tree (like weapons, perks, bonuses, etc.), with you being able to switch between trees at any time.  So that's it with comparisons. So how's the actualy game itself?  It's fast, furious, difficult, and just plain amazing. Assuming you get the Wolfpack DLC (which I highly reccomend) you have 4 skill trees, 9 heists, and all in all a ton of fun. I only have ONE WARNING: DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME ALONE! The AI is so stupid it's embarrasing. You can do it for bragging rights, or for practice, but this game needs to be played with other people, so get a team.  Regarding the community, outside of Europe not that many people play it, so I suggest getting a 4-pack and playing it with friends.  And that's my review! Hopefully you now understand which PAYDAY game is for you! (I reccomend getting both, if you can)  FINAL SUMMARY: This game, and it's sequel, are amazing. Fantastic gameplay, great dev's, and hours upon hours of fun. Just don't do it alone!

When I got PAYDAY 1 on a steam sale, I didn't play it till my friends got it. And now it's one of my favorite games. Even though PAYDAY 2 is out and I find that game really fun, I still come back to this game because the 2 games have 2 different play styles. PAYDAY 2 is more realisic and strategic, while PAYDAY 1 feels like it's more Left 4 Dead or Mass Effect 3 multiplyer. It also feels more fast paced, sending larger waves of enemies in maps that offer poor cover causing the player to use their unlimited sprint, and 0 reduction on your speed due to the armor you must wear to survive, to dodge and return fire on maps that contain both close and long range encounters. Both of the PAYDAY games are on my list of best games I've ever played.  I highly recommend these games.

Imagine Left 4 Dead except you're shooting cops instead of zombies.  There's a level progression system in the game just like in the sequel, but you don't have to worry about any of the RPG ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t elements, just level up and spend points. Imagine more like Killing Floor where playing the game gives you progress on each class. You can grind it out to get there faster, but that'll go against what the game's pushing you towards.  People say it's comparable to Payday 2 in that they're the same characters and world, etc. They're wrong. The game is paced completely differently: heists aren't meant to be quick in-and-out situations, they're long, gruelling marathons you have to push through. They also don't function on an 'all or nothing' reward system. If you fail right at the end, that's okay, you still get money (experience) for every objective you completed along the way. It's not as rage inducing as ♥♥♥♥ing up a Big Bank stealth right as you're opening the vault, then having to run and get the god damn drill because alarms went off.  That's another thing, there's not really stealth save for one or two missions. Don't be a ♥♥♥♥in' ♥♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥♥. When you ask yourself 'Are we rushin' in, or are we goin in sneakypeaky like?', the answer should always be the former. Stealth in this game is a lot harder, and it's more of a dickwaving contest kind of situation when you can stealth the few maps, rather than being the optimal strategy necessarily.  Overall, it's worth picking up even if you have Payday 2. It's not like the Left 4 Dead series in the regards that L4D2 replaces the 1st in every way, they're just completely different games with different mechanics.

When you first start playing, the game is hard as nails and requires strong teamwork and lots of perseverance to get through a heist on the Normal difficulty (only two heists are playable on Easy). However, once you've put in some time and level up, you become better able to survive and succeed. The game's general tempo is great, you're running around on this map constantly under pressure from the police, and periodically they'll send in tougher waves with special enemies like the 'Bulldozer' (a super-armored SWAT trooper), 'Shield' (a trooper with a riot shield, naturally), and 'Cloaker' (a stealthy spec-ops type). There are three 'classes' in the game: assault, sharpshooter, and support. While the difference between them is at first only the guns they use, as you complete missions you'll level up each class and earn more benefits. However, there's not really a system where you pick and choose your benefits: it's straight up 'higher level = better', with no balances at all. One major aspect of the game's 'crime' theme is the hostage concept. Civilians litter each level; shooting them causes police to act more aggressively, but they can be shouted down and zip tied to be used as hostages. If a player-character is caught by the police, they can be traded for a hostage, so in a sense hostages act as 'extra lives'. However, the police will also be trying to rescue the hostages, so maintaining control of them is critical.

Payday is a fun co-op game, but it lacks polish.  The maps are of uneven quality and difficulty. There is frequently a feeling of 'what do I do next?” with inadequate guidance from the game. It helps to play with experienced players, but when you do, you're dragging your team down because you don't have all the levelling perks that they do.  There also seem to be many ways to game each level. Beating levels seems to be less about adapting on the fly, and more about knowing exactly where to hide out while you're waiting for events to happen. And you do spend a lot of time in this game waiting for stuff to happen.  But past the flaws, Payday is a game with a cheap $20 price tag. There is a certain breeziness to the gameplay that's just a rollicking good time. The harder difficulty levels require teamwork and planning, which I appreciate. Payday delivers a satisfying co-op experience, of which there are too few today. Really – if judged solely for its “co-op-iness”, this game is top-flight… playing on a well-coordinated team is a great experience.  I want to mention that you kill a lot of cops in Payday. A lot. Overall, if you like Drill Fixing Simulators I suggest you buy this now, don't hesitate. But in all honesty there are way more Pros than Cons and the cons aren't even that bad. HANDS UP! ON THE GROUND!   PAYDAY: The Heist is one of the best co-op experiences I've had in my life. Even though it has a very limited amount of heists to perform, it has a great value of re-playability. Many of the primary events in each heist are randomized to make each game different.  Regarding the engine, it is superb. Loads really fast, looks good, and feels great. It may have some bugs but considering this was all done by an indie company this is an outstanding job.   The concept behind the game is simple, yet never seen before-- I can't believe they never made a game like this one. There are different heists, one at a bank, with a lot of shootout, other in a secret vault raid in the middle of the night, which has to be silent without setting off alarms, and so on. Each one is played in a different setting.  It also has a great deal of collectibles; there are several masks which can be unlocked throughout the game by doing stuff like reaching a level, finishing a mission, completing a challenge, or finding an Easter egg or a secret.  What's the best about this game? The Easter eggs and references to other elements in pop culture. The first mission is like the movie 'Heat', there are other elements which remind you of 'The Dark Knight'; but the most remarkable of them is the joint operation done by OVERKILL with VALVe to bring a mission set in Left 4 Dead's Mercy Hospital, which hints the beginning of the zombie outbreak.  OVERKILL also designed many Alternate Reality Games inside the game. For instance, the PAYDAY Secret, also known as OVERDRILL, was one of the most important events in the game so far; and the rewarding feeling that many players had while unraveling the secret, is now paid by OVERKILL with a commemorative plaque inside the so called Overvault, with the names of the people who first discovered the secret.  Overall, and even though the game is short and maybe not graphically perfect-- yet it looks very good--, this game is an excellent game and a must have. And if you get the Wolf Pack DLC it's even better, because it expands the game with two more missions and a whole new class to level up, as well as 48 new levels.  Go and grab it on my mark... MARK!

I'll admit, I bought PAYDAY on a whim not expecting that much at it's release. The game sounded interesting, but it was coming from a studio I've not heard from before and while I love some of what SOE's done, they aren't really that well known for retail games. I started up PAYDAY, and started piddling around like I always do.  Originally PAYDAY was kind of a mess. Stability issues were extremely common, leading to frustrating multiplayer experiences along with limited video options available to the player. This felt like a frustrating console port that really didn't play to the PC's strengths and had issues just running in the first place. It was enough for me to shelve it for awhile.  What about now? Well, six months later (yes, I know it's been longer.. shut up) the game has shaped up significantly. More options were exposed to the user including control toggles for movement, the use of sights and an even more awesome and exceedingly well done implementation of Field of View options. While it's difficult to remember just how limited the options were, it's great to see that we have antialiasing, vsync, and detail options that all give a sense of being able to tweak the game to compromise performance and quality based on your own preferences. What's even better is that after this six month simmer period, the game runs beautifully. It's smooth, silky smooth. No hardware replacements on my end, it's just plain awesome. I'm not fighting framerate drops even during the busiest moments and I don't feel like the controls are my enemy as a result.  While most people compare PAYDAY to Left 4 Dead, I find it hard to make that comparison beyond the fact that it shares some gameplay elements. Squad of four, special 'infected' or Police units really is the extent of the similarities (barring any hint at zombie involvement after this review). The game is much more about control of key areas, as far as I've experienced, and less about just simply running and gunning. Sure there's 'Heat Street' which does kind of push for running and gunning, but at the same time the 'weight' of various mechanics just change your mindset to seeking and staying in cover and making a move when you know you won't take much flak for it.  One thing I've always liked about Payday is it's over-the-top response by Law Enforcement. Even with my first experience back in October on First World Bank, I remember staring out the front doors of the bank after finding the last pesky camera to see NYPD squad cars slide in to view with officers jumping out. I recall seeing police officers running by the bullet-proof glass as they made their way to various entrances and I recall the almost perfect escalation of force that was so appropriate for the level.  There are a LOT of little details that make you smile after having seen some of the movies in which the game takes a good deal from, but it's not just animations, style, or heists that borrow from that. There's even a neat-o filter that changes the color palette based on whatever you happen to choose. From movies such as Black Hawk Down all the way to The Matrix, it really can add more to the game's presentation if you let it. Amusingly enough OVERKILL saw fit to add even a few nods at the industry's habits with filters such as 'NextGen Brown' which add a hefty amount of brown as a nod to the Call of Duty, Battlefield, Gears of War, and other modern shooters.  The game isn't perfect, but as a start, it bodes well for OVERKILL. A fun little game that's in the spirit of Left 4 Dead, only this time, you're a gang of robbers raiding banks, drug cartels, billionaire suites and armored trucks for tons of cash. In the spirit of any Valve game worth its salt (although the game itself is NOT made by Valve), you have a decently sized arsenal of weapons and equipment that hold distinct purposes for different situations, and the various enemy types are distinct from one another that you can identify them at a glance. The level up system is fun if a bit grindy and until you get to Reputation 145, everyone's builds will be vastly different.  The most negative part of this game is that (aside from being inferior to its sequel in basically every regard; again, much like Left 4 Dead to its sequel.) the level grinding will overstay its welcome, and unless you're a diehard player, you won't get your character to Reputation 145. The stealth aspect of the Diamond Heist is also a bit dodgy, which is infuriating when you're trying to grab all the sapphires and go for the Big Diamond, the latter of which has an RNG element even on the higher difficulties, which is a cardinal sin.   That being said, if you're looking for a robust shooter or just a big fan of Ocean's Eleven, then this game (and more specifically its sequel) will satisfy.

Title:  'Payday: The Heist'  Developer(s)/publisher(s):  Overkill Software/Sony Online Entertainment  Genre(s):  First-person shooter, Co-op  Mode(s):  Single-player, Co-op  General info:  Payday: The Heist is a 2011 downloadable cooperative first-person shooter video game, that runs on a modified Diesel game engine. It contains seven different missions (including the free 'No Mercy' downloadable content, released on 25 July 2012), with each mission containing random elements which alter the gameplay in subtle ways with the aim of enhancing replayability. On August 7, 2012, the 'Wolf Pack' DLC was released on PS3 and PC. This DLC added two new heists, additional weapons, and a new player upgrade tree.   Gameplay:  In each heist, players are required to complete objectives, usually in an effort to steal cash or valuables. The police will attempt to stop them, but players are expected to fight through them with firearms, except in the case of the mission called 'Diamond Heist', where players can slip past guards unnoticed and acquire diamonds to complete the mission.  The game plays from the first person perspective, but offers a few twists on the standard FPS formula.  Killing civilians is punished, instead players may take a limited number as hostages by intimidating and binding their hands. Should any player get arrested (after taking enough damage and not being 'revived' in time) during the heist, one of the other teammates may release a hostage, allowing a trade to take place which allows this player to be released.  While playing the levels, players will notice a lot of variation in a single level, as there are often a large number of random events programmed in. An example of this is the location of the bank manager in the mission 'First World Bank'. The game features an automated leveling-system, with four different classes/skill trees.  Experience points are earned through completing objectives and lead to leveling up, which in turn lets the player aqquire 1 out of four different skills each level. These skills improve hit accuracy, armor, crowd control or unlocks new weapons and equipment.  The maximum level - which was raised with the DLC Wolf Pack - is 145.  There are five different difficulty options in the game; Easy, Normal, Hard, Overkill and Overkill 145+ (which can only be attempted after reaching the 145:th level).   Story:  Although Payday: The Heist does not focus on any significant single-player plot, the characters and missions do have some backstory.  The game focuses on a four man team of bankrobbers - code-named 'Dallas', 'Hoxton', 'Chains', and 'Wolf' - who team up due to their different skills. They all dress up in suits (or ballistic armor depending on their mission) and don Clown-like masks to hide their appearance.  What they all have in common are troubled lives, monetary debts and bad memories. As the 'Payday-crew', they join up for a criminal spree, looking to be 'set for life'.  Chronologically, the team's first heist took place at the First World Bank, where they entered a vault by using thermite hidden inside the bank by an insideman and stole a large amount of money before blasting a hole through a wall and escaping through the neighbouring building.  Working for a mysterious criminal hacker codenamed 'Bane', whom they receive orders and directions from, they are given different kinds of missions. These missions are generally centered on robbery, kidnapping, and occassionally assassination.   My opinions:  I first discovered this game in March 2012, about half a year after it's release here on Steam. I heard about it from a friend, who had bought it earlier and he recommended it to me (Thx a lot for that, Max!).  I bought it a while later and we started playing together (although my friend soon got way ahead of me level-wise).  Payday: The Heist may have been developed by a studio that was quite small at the time of it's release, but that only makes it even more impressing.  I really enjoy this game, although I play it's sequel ('Payday 2') a lot more these days.  Still, in my opinion Payday: The Heist offers harder challenges than it's sequel in terms of missions and the game's achievements are worth the time it may take to accomplish them!  It's a definitive must buy, although the standard price of 14,99 euro might be a little high - waiting for a sale is the best option.  I recommend this game to all people who love FPS co-op or simply want to don a Clown-mask and rob some banks.   Buy this game, and remember; 'Keep those helmets flying!'

The bots won't help you accomplish hard tasks. The Heisters don't understand the concept of closing doors or bringing at least one flashbang/smokebomb/thermal vision set of their own.  The leveling is class-linear; while you can choose to level up any class, once it's done up, it'll give you the same package deal like eveyone else. You need to buy the Wolf Pack DLC to unlock the Technician class.  There is no mod support. It doesn't have a VS mode where you can play the cops. The engine isn't being used by anyone else these days. The models, while nice, could use some work to be prettier. Sometimes enemies can glitch around and pop through collision walls. The textures here and there could use some work. There are only nine maps, seven if you haven't bought the Wolf Pack (tho anyone with DLC can host the maps for anyone without them).  Normally... all this would make me wonder if this game is worth it.  It's totally worth it. It's addictive and requires far more sophisticated teamwork than something similar like the Left 4 Dead series (which this draws example from), even with the challenges that game poses in it's many game modes.  Perhaps most importantly, the game seems incredibly optimised for the net; I've played many games online with poor sync between the players but the Deisel Engine's netcode tends to run quite efficiently. In this game, it seems even bad ping is king and this certainly isn't some Saints Row 2 netcode nightmare!  So even with all of it's flagging qualities, this is a stellar entry into the 4-player Coop games that trumps many of it's contenders surprisingly and delivers on it's pricetag like few other games today.  Now if only Starbreeze can make the sequel superior...

I am not saying that PAYDAY: The Heist is necessarily a bad game, but it can get repetitive very quickly, even if you are playing with friends. I've owned a copy of PayDay: The Heist for a while -- nearly a month, in fact -- and although I've played plenty of other games since this download arrived, PayDay memories still bring a smile to my face. Nix getting killed outside the bank vault over and over again, exchanging my first hostage for a teammate, Ben Dickens and I massacring a SWAT team while monitoring the second floor of a drug den -- this game turned the IGN office into a screaming match. PayDay: The Heist is stiff and unintuitive in spots, but the overall package is a fun and a welcome addition to the PlayStation Network.   PayDay: The Heist Video Review If you've seen Point Break or played Left 4 Dead, wrapping your head around PayDay: The Heist is easy. A cooperative first-person shooter, PayDay casts you and three bots or online friends as thieves and gives you six different jobs to go out on. Missions range from a bank heist to breaking out a prisoner to getting away from a job gone wrong, and enemy tactics change depending on how you're tackling a job.  When I first started playing, I assumed these situations would get stale as the mission objectives don't change -- you're always doing the same action in the same place -- but PayDay keeps it interesting with its dynamic leveling system. Your character evolves as you play and that tweaks the game's various heists. Each time you level up, you unlock a new weapon, item or bonus from the experience tree you have active. See, there are three trees and you can switch between them at any time. This is important to point out in the review because PayDay never explains this system in the game. I had to call the folks behind PayDay to get an explanation of how the trees work. PayDay's menus tend to just throw text at you and leave you to figure it out. I'm sure most people will do just that, but I know some folks will just walk away in frustration.  That's a shame because the skill trees are worth getting to the bottom of -- there are more than 140 levels to achieve. Once you get an established crew together, you can build teams where everyone has a specialized function. You can have a medic, an ammo man, a dude whose sole job is to handcuff hostages; it all depends on which tree a given player has been investing in. That kind of role-playing is great for people who want to nerd out and plan missions.  Playing heists over and over again is the point of PayDay. Each time I started a job, I was out to do better than the time before. I'd warn new teammates about faulty drills, coordinate taking out security cameras, and call out cops that needed to be wiped out. It was actually a bit creepy (yet thrilling) how well my friends and I transitioned into the role of criminals. We'd pull our guns, put on our clown masks, and begin working as a unit. Cue the in-office screaming and me loving the atmosphere.   Get off my roof.  But make no mistake about it, the 'we' was a big part of the good time. PayDay: The Heist packs a single-player option that pairs you with AI teammates, but it's only good for getting to know the maps and working on leveling up. The game shines when you play it with friends using headsets, and even then, dumb enemies and stiff gunplay can spoil some people's good time.  PayDay really stumbles when it comes to presentation and polish. Objectives populate every map and change as the job progresses (go here, bomb this, capture that). However, the game doesn't bother explaining them all that well. There's a part in the first mission where you have to wait for a fire to eat through a bank vault's ceiling, and every time someone new played with me, they'd think we missed something or screwed something up as the fire just burns and burns and burns. There's no countdown, and the majority of the references to the process are in-game audio lines that get lost when players are jabbering at each other.  The game just feels clunky at times whether it's an enemy spawning from thin air or someone clipping through a wall.  THE VERDICT If you're looking for fun co-op multiplayer on the cheap, PayDay: The Heist fits the bill at $20. I enjoyed my time with it and want to play more with my friends. Working together to get the loot and the insanity of trying to get out alive are tense, enjoyable experiences. Issues like the clipping and generally 'blah' presentation keep PayDay from being an amazing experience, but they don't stop it from being a good time.

Payday: The Heist by Overkill Software is an amazing game and the best out of the 2 Payday games.   PayDay 1 puts you in a crime group tha goes around and pulls off heists while trying not to get killed/arrested by the police.  You can play as either Chains, Hoxton, Wolf or Dallas. Each Character has a unique personality to them so they dont get boring after playing for a while.  The Game offers 6 different heists in the base game while the DLC adds another 2-3 heists. You can rob a bank, pull off a diamond heist, etc.   Reputation levels is the XP system in the game, you gain Reputation by completing objectives during heists, picking up small money bundles in the heists, completing challenges and finishing heists. Each time you level your Rep you gain upgrades to weapons, upgrades to your characters health, and a variety of other rewards that can be used to benefit you in the heist.  The guns are very well balanced and different from each other so no weapon is better than the other. however the number of guns in the game are a tad low its not something that bothers me because each weapon is good at something. You a good sharpshooter? Grab the M308 and pick off Police Snipers at longe ranges. You like to run and gun? Grab either the AMCAR Assault rifle or the Reinback Shotgun and annahilate the police forces. You more of a support player? Grab the Brenner LMG and cover your teammates as they complete objectives. Or maybe you want to blow things up? Get the Wolf Pack DLC and you can get the GL40 Grenade Launcher which is perfect for clearing civilain free rooms filled with cops.    Different Types of Police Units:    - Guards : these are your basic enemies. they are only armed with pistols and easy to take down. - Police Officers : Another basic enemy but this time they can be armed with not only pistols but also shotguns making them deadly at close ranges. - FBI Agents : Another basic Enemy that is only armed with Pistols but has light body armour. - S.W.A.T : SWAT Officers are a little tougher because they have light armour and can carry SMGs which makes them an annoyance at medium range combat. - Heavy S.W.A.T : These guys are tough. They have heavy armour and can carry either Shotguns, SMGs or Assault Rifles. - Police Snipers : These guys hide on rooftops and other high places to try and pick your team off from long ranges. These guys hit hard so be careful when these guys show up.    Special Police Units   - Shields : These guys are Heavy SWAT officers that carry a bullet proof shield into combat that will make it tough for you to kill not only them but the other police units. You can tell when a Shield is near because he bangs on his shield a couple times - Tasers : Taser Officers can be a really pain the butt. These guys will tase you till you are incapped or until a teammate shoots them or you shoot the taser. You can tell when a Taser is in the area by hearing him charge up his taser and by the Yellow Shoulder Plates on the officers Armour. - Cloakers : Cloakers are a huge threat to heists because of their speed and instant incap if you let them get to close. The only way to tell if a cloaker is near is by his Green light on his Nightvision goggles other than that they are silent strikers. Be on your toes. - The Bulldozer : The Bulldozer is an officer in really heavy body armour and a bullet resistant helmet. These guys are armed with Shotguns and arent afraid to waltz right in on your team and ruin the WHOLE heist in a matter of seconds.  Overrall this game is an amazing game. The Gameplay is very good and doesnt get boring after a while. The variety of guns and enemies make the heists a challenge at several points. Playing with Friends makes the game 100 times more fun. I Highly Suggest you buy this game over Payday 2.   I give this game a 9.5 out of 10
